introduction.p: You may save your work at any time by clicking on Save. When you are finished working, click on Submit and Finish, a pop up window will ask "This will submit your answers and finish this assignment. Are you sure?", click "OK" if you are ready to submit your answers for final grading.
If you close this window without having saved or submitted, your changes will be lost. After pressing Submit and Finish, please wait for your answers to be scored. Do NOT click on it more than once.

body.p: Complete the following: Hydrostatic Pressure – Resistance from fluid in the tubule – Osmotic Collodial Pressure =

feedback.p: Incorrect. Blood Osmotic Collodial Pressure is part of the equation, but not the result of the equation.
Incorrect. Capsular hydrostatic pressure is part of the equation, but not the result of the equation.

Correct. Three forces affect the rate of glomerular filtration; one enhances filtration, and two resist it. Subtracting the opposing pressures (Resistance from fluid in the tubule, Osmotic Collodial Pressure) from the promoting pressure (Hydrostatic pressure) yields the net filtration pressure.

Incorrect. The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is another type of equation. Specifically, GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time.

body.p: The GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time. The average GFR is about per minute, which equals about per day.

feedback.p: Correct. The GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time.
Incorrect. The GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time.
Incorrect. The GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time.
Incorrect. The GFR is the total amount of filtrate formed by the two million renal corpuscles in the kidneys divided by time.
Correct. The average GFR is about 125 milliliters/4 ounces per minute, which equals about 140 liters/50 gallons per day.
Incorrect. The average GFR is about 125 milliliters/4 ounces per minute, which equals about 140 liters/50 gallons per day.
Incorrect. The average GFR is about 125 milliliters/4 ounces per minute, which equals about 140 liters/50 gallons per day.
Incorrect. The average GFR is about 125 milliliters/4 ounces per minute, which equals about 140 liters/50 gallons per day.

body.p: Most reabsorption is performed by cells located in

input.choice: the length of the renal tubule.
along the length of the collecting duct.
renal tubule, proximal convoluted tubule, and along the length of the collecting duct.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Reabsorption returns about 99 percent of filtered water and many filtered solutes to the bloodstream. Although epithelial cells all along the length of the renal tubule and the collecting duct contribute, cells in the proximal convoluted tubule perform most reabsorption.

Correct. Reabsorption returns about 99 percent of filtered water and many filtered solutes to the bloodstream. Although epithelial cells all along the length of the renal tubule and the collecting duct contribute, cells in the proximal convoluted tubule perform most reabsorption.

Incorrect. Reabsorption returns about 99 percent of filtered water and many filtered solutes to the bloodstream. Although epithelial cells all along the length of the renal tubule and the collecting duct contribute, cells in the proximal convoluted tubule perform most reabsorption.

Incorrect. Reabsorption returns about 99 percent of filtered water and many filtered solutes to the bloodstream. Although epithelial cells all along the length of the renal tubule and the collecting duct contribute, cells in the proximal convoluted tubule perform most reabsorption.

body.p: The ratio of water and solutes in glomerular filtrate is the _____ as that in blood, with an osmolarity of around _________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The ratio of water and solutes in glomerular filtrate is the same as that in blood, with an osmolarity of around 300 mOsm/liter. An osmolarity of 600 mOsm/liter would be too high.
Incorrect. The ratio of water and solutes in glomerular filtrate is the same, not more dilute, as that in blood, with an osmolarity of around 300 mOsm/liter.
Incorrect. The ratio of water and solutes in glomerular filtrate is the same, not less dilute, as that in blood, with an osmolarity of around 300 mOsm/liter.
Correct. The ratio of water and solutes in glomerular filtrate is the same as that in blood, with an osmolarity of around 300 mOsm/liter.

body.p: In countercurrent exchange, _____________ ions diffuse from the medullary interstitial fluid into the blood, which then allows water to diffuse from the blood into the interstitial fluid.

feedback.p: Incorrect. In countercurrent exchange, countercurrent flow enables the passive exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the medullary interstitial fluid. In its descending limb, urea and sodium and chloride ions diffuse from the increasingly concentrated medullary interstitial fluid into the blood, while water diffuses from the blood into the interstitial fluid.

Incorrect. In countercurrent exchange, countercurrent flow enables the passive exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the medullary interstitial fluid. In its descending limb, urea and sodium and chloride ions diffuse from the increasingly concentrated medullary interstitial fluid into the blood, while water diffuses from the blood into the interstitial fluid.

Incorrect. In countercurrent exchange, countercurrent flow enables the passive exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the medullary interstitial fluid. In its descending limb, urea and sodium and chloride ions diffuse from the increasingly concentrated medullary interstitial fluid into the blood, while water diffuses from the blood into the interstitial fluid.

Correct. In countercurrent exchange, countercurrent flow enables the passive exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the medullary interstitial fluid. In its descending limb, urea and sodium and chloride ions diffuse from the increasingly concentrated medullary interstitial fluid into the blood, while water diffuses from the blood into the interstitial fluid.

body.p: The countercurrent multiplication mechanism is responsible for the establishment of an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium, which is the primary responsibility of the

feedback.p: Correct. The loop of Henle is responsible for the countercurrent multiplication mechanism that establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium.

Incorrect. Countercurrent multiplication mechanism establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium. The loop of Henle is responsible for the countercurrent multiplication mechanism that establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium.

Incorrect. Countercurrent multiplication mechanism establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium. The loop of Henle is responsible for the countercurrent multiplication mechanism that establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium.

Incorrect. Countercurrent exchange occurs in the vasa recta. The loop of Henle is responsible for the countercurrent multiplication mechanism that establishes an osmotic gradient within the medullary interstitium.

body.p: If delaying of micturition is necessary, the reflex bladder contractions will temporarily stop, but urine continues accumulating. However, the addition of another of urine will again prompt another micturition reflex for a stronger urge to urinate.

feedback.p: Incorrect. If we need to delay micturition, reflex bladder contractions will temporarily stop but urine will continue accumulating. The addition of another 7 to 10 ounces of urine will again prompt another micturition reflex. When more than 500 to 600 milliliters (about 20 ounces) of urine accumulates, urination will occur. After micturition, about 10 milliliters (0.33 ounces) of urine will remain in the bladder.

Incorrect. If we need to delay micturition, reflex bladder contractions will temporarily stop but urine will continue accumulating. The addition of another 7 to 10 ounces of urine will again prompt another micturition reflex. When more than 500 to 600 milliliters (about 20 ounces) of urine accumulates, urination will occur. After micturition, about 10 milliliters (0.33 ounces) of urine will remain in the bladder.

Correct. If we need to delay micturition, reflex bladder contractions will temporarily stop but urine will continue accumulating. The addition of another 7 to 10 ounces of urine will again prompt another micturition reflex. When more than 500 to 600 milliliters (about 20 ounces) of urine accumulates, urination will occur. After micturition, about 10 milliliters (0.33 ounces) of urine will remain in the bladder.

Incorrect. If we need to delay micturition, reflex bladder contractions will temporarily stop but urine will continue accumulating. The addition of another 7 to 10 ounces of urine will again prompt another micturition reflex. When more than 500 to 600 milliliters (about 20 ounces) of urine accumulates, urination will occur. After micturition, about 10 milliliters (0.33 ounces) of urine will remain in the bladder.
